text.title: Abitibi
text.head: Abitibi
text.p: Abitibi, or Abitibi-Temiscamingue as it is officially called, is a region of Quebec.
text.head: Cities

list.item: —Abitibi-Témiscamingue's capital, it is often referred to as "La capitale nationale du Cuivre" (National Copper Capital).
–Small (pop 2950) forestry town on the Bell River.

text.head: Other destinations
Understand
Talk
text.p: Despite its proximity to Ontario, Abitibi has surprisingly few native English speakers. Most people here speak French, but young people may understand and speak English. Aboriginal languages are spoken increasingly infrequently in reserves.
text.head: Get in
By car

list.item: From Montréal, route 117 passes through the Réserve Faunique de La Vérendrye.
From Chibougamau, route 113 passes via Senneterre
From northern Québec (Nord-du-Québec), route 109 passes via Amos.
From northeastern Ontario, route 66 passes from Kirkland Lake, Ontario to Arntfield. Route 101 between Matheson, Ontario, and Duparquet, Quebec may be shorter, but it is isolated and narrow.
From North Bay, route 63 reaches Témiscaming.
From Temiskaming Shores, route 65 reaches Notre-Dame-du-Nord.

text.head: By train

list.item: Via Rail, toll-free: +1 888 VIA-RAIL . offers a few weekly runs from Montreal region to Senneterre station which take about eleven and a half hours. $193 return.

text.head: By bus
text.p: Autobus Maheux runs daily between the principal towns and cities in the region, offering three departures daily to and from Montréal. The trip to Val d'Or takes about seven hours and costs about $82 (one adult, in 2009). The same company provides connections to Ontario (North Bay) and James Bay (connection at Chibougamau).
text.head: By plane
text.p: There is regular service to Rouyn-Noranda ( YUY ) from Montreal.
